The actual word “hoedown” is American in its roots. More specifically, it is likely to have originated in America’s mid-west. It is generally believed that the word is a literal derivation of putting a “hoe down”. It is easy to romanticise visions of the early American farming communities in those wild days of yore.

In contest fiddling, a hoedown is a tune in fast 2/4 time. In many contests, fiddlers are required to play a waltz, a hoedown, and a tune of choice, which must not be a waltz or a hoedown (typically it is a jig or a schottische). In the 1940s and early 1950s, the term hoedown was sometimes used to mean a call made up of parts of other calls. Hoedown was, and occasionally still is, also used to mean a dance jointly sponsored by several dance clubs or by a federation of clubs. Hoedown Throwdown  is a song performed by American recording artist Miley Cyrus, combining elements of country pop, dance pop, and hip hop, It was released as a single from the soundtrack for Hannah Montana: The Movie. Hoedown Throwdown is written in the key of E♭ major. Cyrus' vocals span two octaves, from B♭ 3 to F 5. The song begins with an intro in which Cyrus repeats Boom Boom clap, boom di-clap di-clap four times. This line is reused in the song's outro.
